CARDINAL . In submissions filed with the President of ORG , counsel for the ORG objected , in particular , that the applicants had not applied for judicial review of the decisions of the Commissioner ORG or for a stay of their execution .

CARDINAL . By an order of CARDINAL DATE the President of ORG Instance ordered the ORG to allow the applicants to leave the transit zone freely and without restriction , with a penalty of ORG TIME with effect from notification of the order in the event of failure to comply .
The decision delivered in the context of application no . CARDINAL reads as follows :
“ It is common ground that the applicant is at present subject to a decision of DATE to remove him from national territory , upheld on DATE .

The time - limit for bringing an action for a stay of execution and for judicial review does not have suspensive effect ; nor does the application for regularisation under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW of DATE which the applicant submitted on DATE .
As the applicant 's administrative status is binding on the court , it must take note of the fact that the applicant is therefore not entitled to remain on NORP territory .
Nonetheless , the decision of ORG is also binding on the court and in the present case , that division ordered the applicant 's immediate release .

It is also common ground that ORG was aware of the applicant 's administrative status and in particular of the decision of the CGRA and therefore ordered his release with full knowledge of the facts .
It is not for this court to adjudicate on that status but , rather , on the way in which that decision to release the applicant is implemented by ORG , all other things being equal .

The defendant maintains that , in view of the fact that the applicant has not been authorised to enter national territory as such , it was correct to take the view that the applicant 's release should be effected in the transit zone , since that zone is not an area where the law does not apply but is in fact part of the GPE for persons in transit in GPE and those who have not yet been authorised to enter the national territory as such .

ORG has held that ' as regards the access , residence , establishment and removal of aliens , it does not follow from the legal distinction between the port area and the rest of the territory of the GPE that the transit zone is not part of the GPE and that the law referred to does not apply there ' ( Court of Cassation , DATE , Pas . DATE , CARDINAL ) .

The closed centres are in reality nothing more than extensions of the transit zones , antechambers to the territory of the GPE , the only difference being that , unlike the transit zone , they are designed to be capable of accommodating persons for a more or less long period in what are assumed to be decent conditions .

While the defendant 's reasoning can therefore be followed in so far as it considers that by being present in the transit zone the applicant was in fact on NORP territory , that reasoning can not be followed where it considers that such presence amounts to ' release ' .

It can not be accepted that the legislature , by creating centres at the borders , specially equipped to accommodate persons who are being held pending leave to enter the GPE or pending deportation , and by providing that persons held in those centres have a right of appeal to the chambre du conseil , took the view that if their release was ordered by the chambre du conseil and then by ORG , those persons could be sent to the transit zone , which is wholly unequipped to receive them , since this would place them in an even more precarious and adverse situation .

If release limited to the transit centre were to be accepted , that would amount to allowing the NORP State unilaterally to block a court decision ordering release on the basis of a person 's administrative status , when that administrative status had been taken into consideration by that court and must have constituted a ground of its decision ordering release .
Since DATE the parties have both known that the removal order is enforceable , since the applicant 's appeal to the CGRA was rejected and no urgent application for a stay of its execution was made .
Since then the applicant has shown no intention of complying voluntarily with the removal order .
Nor has ORG forcibly removed him since then .

Since the ORG is now required to comply with the decision ordering the applicant 's release , there are CARDINAL possibilities : either the defendant prefers to wait until the applicant decides to leave voluntarily , but in that case , while awaiting his departure , the ORG must allow him to move freely within the territory ( in observance of res judicata ) , or the defendant assumes its responsibilities and provides itself with the means to enforce the order for the applicant 's return in order to ensure compliance with its own administrative decisions .
In that regard , the PERSON allows ORG to order the alien in question to reside in a specified place pending implementation of the order for his removal ( section QUANTITY of DATE ) .

What is unacceptable and contrary to the rule of law in the present case is that the NORP State should place the applicant in another closed place ( the transit zone ) in which the living conditions are inhuman and degrading , in the hope that the applicant will then decide to implement the removal order ' voluntarily ' .
In transferring the applicant from the closed centre at NORP to the transit zone , ORG committed an illegal act .

On the basis of the file as it currently stands , the release ordered by ORG necessarily means that , until such time as he is removed , the applicant is free to leave the transit zone , without prejudice to the ORG 's right to order the applicant to reside in a specific place ( section CARDINAL ) .
That solution to a wholly contradictory situation is the CARDINAL possible if the procedure under section CARDINAL of the Act of DATE is not to be reduced to a farce .
In the light of the foregoing , the application must be allowed in accordance with the operative part of the present order . ”
The decision delivered in connection with application no . CARDINAL is based on the same reasoning .

CARDINAL . The applicants stated that the transit zone had no bedrooms and , a fortiori , no beds , and that they were housed in the mosque located there . They were taken in by the NORP counsellor , who took them in again after the various attempts to remove them .
